WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Why SWIFT and Ripple Are Really Competing for Institutional Legitimacy, Not Technology
Source: CCN.com    Published: 2025-11-10 14:51:10

Why SWIFT and Ripple Are Really Competing for Institutional Legitimacy, Not Technology | Credit: Veronica Cestari /CCN Key Takeaways The main issue between Ripple and SWIFT lies in a simple question: how global money moves. Ripple enables real-time settlements through blockchain-based technology that transfers value between digital wallets across its RippleNet network. This process removes the need for multiple intermediaries and minimizes the capital that banks must hold in pre-funded accounts. SWIFT, by contrast, coordinates cross-border payments through its global messaging infrastructure used by more than 11,000 financial institutions and in more than 200 countries and territories. It does not move money directly but sends secure payment instructions through applications that connect participating banks' internal systems. Their competition is about which one financial institution can rely on to support global finance. Ripple introduces transparency and near instant settlement, while SWIFT maintains its strength through regulatory integration, trust, and decades of operational stability. This article explains how the rivalry extends beyond technology to the deeper questions of credibility, regulatory alignment, and liquidity efficiency, showing why institutional trust continues to shape the future of global payments. Because SWIFT and Ripple provide fundamentally different services, the question almost answers itself. SWIFT manages the messaging layer that instructs payments between banks, while Ripple handles the actual movement of value across its blockchain network. You'll Want To See This EXCHANGES HOW TO BUY CRYPTO EXCHANGES SAFEST CRYPTO EXCHANGES They address related parts of the same problem, which raises the question of whether they can work together or must remain competitors. Both systems are scaling rapidly, but their growth underscores different strengths: SWIFT's reach and compliance depth contrast with Ripple's agility and expanding use of blockchain for liquidity management. This divergence sets the stage for technical convergence under shared standards like ISO 20022. In 2025, SWIFT also began testing blockchain integrations such as its Linea pilot with ConsenSys, signaling its intent to modernize settlement infrastructure while maintaining regulatory oversight. In short, SWIFT and Ripple operate in the same ecosystem but from different angles. SWIFT evolves within the established banking framework, while Ripple continues to innovate outside it. Their coexistence may depend on how interoperability between the two systems develops in the years ahead. As global finance moves toward unified messaging and settlement standards, ISO 20022 has emerged as the shared framework linking traditional payment systems and blockchain networks. It creates a structured language for financial data, allowing legacy institutions and new technologies to communicate seamlessly. This shift is making interoperability between SWIFT and Ripple increasingly practical. SWIFT's migration to ISO 20022 and Ripple's early compliance with the standard establish a foundation where both can operate within the same ecosystem while maintaining their distinct functions. Some key points are the following: In short, ISO 20022 acts as the bridge between traditional finance and blockchain-based networks. It enables data interoperability, reduces friction in cross-border transactions, and lays the groundwork for a future where SWIFT and Ripple can coexist within a unified payment infrastructure. Ripple's DLT is technically faster. However, the debate runs deeper than transaction speed. Ripple's distributed-ledger technology enables quick processing, but institutions weigh other factors before adopting a system at scale. As a result, trust and reliability remain the true battleground. While Ripple challenges traditional inefficiencies, SWIFT's institutional network still defines trust in global finance. The market is projected to reach $320.73 billion by 2030, growing at a 7.1% CAGR from 2025, driven by e-commerce and ISO 20022 adoption. The competition between SWIFT and Ripple is unlikely to produce a single winner. Instead, the future of global payments is heading toward a segmented model where both systems serve different markets and transaction types. In this hybrid future, SWIFT maintains its role as the backbone of institutional finance, while Ripple grows as a complementary network that addresses liquidity constraints and near-instant payments. The dividing line will not be technological capability but rather institutional purpose with both systems coexisting in a global architecture that prioritizes interoperability. The rivalry between SWIFT and Ripple has become a driver of innovation rather than conflict. SWIFT maintains its position as the backbone of institutional finance, trusted for security, governance, and global reliability. Ripple, meanwhile, advances a more agile model powered by distributed-ledger technology, removing the inefficiencies of pre-funded cross-border accounts. The adoption of ISO 20022 unites both systems under a single data framework, allowing greater efficiency and communication across networks. Global payments are moving toward collaboration, where legacy infrastructure and blockchain technology work together to create a faster, more transparent, and resilient financial ecosystem. Which markets are leading Ripple's adoption? Asia-Pacific leads Ripple's ODL usage, accounting for over half of its transaction volume in 2025. Can SWIFT and Ripple operate within the same transaction? Yes. A payment can start through SWIFT for compliance messaging and finish on RippleNet for instant settlement. What does the future of global payments look like? A hybrid system where SWIFT handles high-value regulated transfers and Ripple powers faster, lower-value transactions. How does Ripple's ODL improve liquidity management? ODL removes the need for pre-funded Nostro/Vostro accounts by settling payments instantly across currencies. Asia-Pacific leads Ripple's ODL usage, accounting for over half of its transaction volume in 2025. Yes. A payment can start through SWIFT for compliance messaging and finish on RippleNet for instant settlement. A hybrid system where SWIFT handles high-value regulated transfers and Ripple powers faster, lower-value transactions. ODL removes the need for pre-funded Nostro/Vostro accounts by settling payments instantly across currencies.

Hong Kong to Issue Third Blockchain-Based Green Bond Sale: Bloomberg
Source: CoinDesk    Published: 2025-11-10 12:52:02

Hong Kong is preparing to issue a new batch of government-backed digital green bonds, deepening its move into blockchain-based finance as it tries to position itself as a leading global hub for tokenized assets. The offering, Hong Kong's third digital bond sale since 2023, will be denominated in US dollars, euros, offshore yuan and Hong Kong dollars, Bloomberg reported citing sources familiar with the issuance. Pricing could be finalized as early as today. These are so-called digitally native bonds, meaning they are created and settled entirely on blockchain-based platforms. The infrastructure for this latest issue will come from HSBC. The green label indicates that the funds raised will go toward environmental or climate-focused projects. The city has been pushing to become a blockchain hub, while facing competition from other regions including Singapore and Dubai. Appetite for blockchain-based debt appears to be growing. Corporations have issued at least six tokenized bonds in the city so far, raising a combined $1 billion, according to the report. Recent issuers include state-backed firms like Shenzhen Futian Investment Holdings and Shandong Hi-Speed Holdings Group. S&P gave the notes an AA+ rating. According to the firm, risks tied to digital issuance are buffered by a fail-safe that allows the bonds to shift back into traditional systems if needed. More For You Inside Zcash: Encrypted Money at Planetary Scale A deep dive into Zcash's zero-knowledge architecture, shielded transaction growth, and its path to becoming encrypted Bitcoin at scale. How Experts Break Down Crypto Price Volatility in Educational Presentations
Source: The Singju Post    Published: 2025-11-10 12:31:19

The Singju Post The Singju Post While the crypto market continues to grow and proliferate worldwide, investors, teachers and political analysts have become increasingly interested in comprehending its price dynamics. During speeches and conferences, professionals strive to unwrap crypto volatility's regularities and digital asset dynamics-determining forces. Cryptocurrency education has transitioned from really niche, specialty online forums to big conferences and scholarly seminars. Experts now devote entire sessions to explaining how market dynamics, human behavior and technology influence value. Understanding crypto prices requires translating technical data into clear, relatable insights that empower your learners to grasp the movement of this rapidly growing asset class. Whenever you discuss digital assets, you need to start with volatility, the crypto market's heartbeat. Unlike traditional securities that transact in long-tested paradigms, digital coins interact in an environment that is still growing. Their decentralized nature, global 7/24 trade cycle and dynamic regulation ensure that price variations remain more volatile than those of other markets. With existing Binance data of “over 9,510 cryptocurrencies with a total market cap of $4,215.22,” there is a wide asset scope, increasing volatility due to the uneven liquidity distribution. It's largely concentrated in Bitcoin and Ethereum, with tiny altcoins subject to huge changes from even small transactions. Educators in the classroom routinely indicate that volatility, although difficult, is not necessarily bad. It is an expression of innovation, investor attitudes and the rate at which new technologies are being implemented internationally. For students, knowing that volatility is just an expression of the growth phase of their market is an important point that breeds patience and a long-view mindset, not alarm. For the majority of pitches, professionals point to market size and liquidity as the core of price stability. While the cryptocurrency market is significant, it remains smaller than regular currency or stock markets. When describing this phenomenon, speakers will refer to comparisons with real-world markets. To use an analogy, if you sell a billion dollars' worth of gold, it would barely affect the price of gold. If you place an equivalently-sized trade in cryptocurrency, however, it could swing prices wildly in minutes. This helps students and audiences understand that liquidity gaps contribute to sharp movements. Professors also refer to the involvement of trading bots and algorithms, wherein volatility in seasons of market strain or swift momentum may increase. Here, the intention is not to shock but to put in perspective. They reveal that such movements result from a dynamic financial system and not signals of volatility. Cryptocurrency specialists who work in education face challenges. Most notably, converting tech data into ideas that the masses can understand. There is so much technical data in the blockchain space, from market state and total value taken (TVL) to hash rates and token circulations, that converting these digits to narratives enables audiences to perceive trends instead of randomness. For instance, when presenters discuss 58.5% Bitcoin dominance, they don't read off of numbers, rather, they contextualize it as an expression of faith in the oldest and most established cryptocurrency versus newer, higher-risk substitutes. This framing helps newcomers connect data to meaning, in turn this fosters a deeper understanding of how capital flows through the ecosystem. By using charts, pictures and comparisons, presenters make the technical aspects of blockchain less mysterious. It's not about simplifying too much, it's about making dynamics in the market accessible and basis in real-world sense. Even professors team up with data visualization designers in order to create live dashboard monitoring the performance and sentiment in real time, conveying abstract economics in living, interactive narrative. Human psychology is responsible for influencing digital asset behavior in an essential role. When you give educational talks, this often emerges as a focal point, the way excitement, fear and speculation can drive sudden market movements. Price spikes, for instance, may not necessarily result from technological innovation or institutional uptake. At times, they're ignited by narratives on social media, calls from thought leaders, or viral community trends. On the other hand, sudden drops result from regulatory pronouncements or global confusion. This interplay of value and emotion itself makes for a feedback loop.Educators encourage audiences to see that while crypto represents cutting-edge technology, it is still subject to human behavior. Grasping market psychology is therefor just as important as comprehending blockchain itself. By revealing the emotional motivators behind data, presenters provide audiences with interpretative tools to gauge volatility more thoughtfully and less frantically. Educational presenters are increasingly turning to visual instruments (graphs, dashboards and real-time data feeds) in order to render volatility's abstract nature concrete. Platforms that show actual-time price discrepancies enable members of the audience to see markets respond to breaking stories or world events. Educators show students interactive charts, so they see how Bitcoin's price, for instance, reacts to changes in market sentiment or liquidity. When put in visuals, the lightning-fast changes that characterize crypto trading start to make more sense. Students get to actually see the market's rhythm; its surges, corrections and stabilization. Such visualization not only facilitates more understanding but also introduces clarity to an otherwise darkly criticized market for its obscurity. For policymaker and student alike, witnessing the data in real-time closes the gap from speculation to insight. It reinforces that beneath the noise, markets move in accordance with recognizable patterns and principles. Numbers alone do not engage, stories do. That's why effective presenters craft stories from the numbers, converting raw data into commonplace understanding. For example, instead of just demonstrating that Ethereum is worth $4,488.98 USD, speakers could place it in Ethereum's larger context; from experimental smart contract platform to decentralized finance bedrock. When put in context like that, numbers make sense and audiences connect market value to technological advancements. These narrative styles make the presentation interesting and memorable. They enable the masses to understand that these digital currencies are not mere numbers in abstraction but manifestations of innovation, experimenting and maturing trust in decentralized economies. Economists condense blockchain economics to its essence by emphasizing fundamentals of scarcity, utility and network participation. With these three rules, much of the value in digital assets is explained. When audiences understand that Bitcoin's supply is capped or that Ethereum's demand rises as more applications are built on its network, they begin to see why value fluctuates. Economic principles are familiar, even if technology is not. Many speakers also cite institutional developments as markers of maturity. As Binance Research notes, “The total crypto market cap lost more than US300B this week, falling to US$3.7T towards the end of the week. Riskier assets like altcoins fell the most, with Ethereum falling over 13% and Solana by 20%. BNB fell only by ~3% while BTC slipped ~6%.” Such data-driven context reinforces to your audience the message that crypto behaves as a real, responsive market, not a speculative bubble detached from fundamentals. Most effective presenters interactivity gives to the education of cryptocurrency. They ask questions, poll their audience and employ simulations to demonstrate key principles. They induce critical thinking and fill in the gap that separates technical competence from popular understanding. Live participation also humanizes a subject that may otherwise be abstract. By turning lectures into discussions, educators create a space where curiosity and skepticism can coexist. The outcome is not persuasion, but understanding, a recognition of how innovation, volatility, and global participation intersect in shaping the crypto ecosystem. Several professionals indicate that demographics of audiences also shift. Presentations once filled with early adopters now see policymakers, designers and entrepreneurs who seek to know how blockchain might transform industries. Such audience diversification highlights crypto's widening application beyond the domain of money. Another prominent theme in teaching sessions is regulation; an aspect that usually decides the state of crypto on the world map. Speakers discuss the role policies play in forming liquidity, innovation and investor sentiment without touching on political reviews. Recent Binance Research has emphasized the fact. “The CFTC's push to evaluate tokenized collateral and stablecoins for derivatives markets highlights a clear regulatory shift toward embracing blockchain-based financial infrastructure. This move could unlock 24/7 liquidity, lower systemic risk and pave the way for broader digital asset adoption.” Educators use such statements to demonstrate that the conversation around crypto is maturing. Instead of fighting off supervision, the sector is now collaborating with the regulators to develop sustainable regimes. Speakers stress that innovators and the regulators must collaborate in order to earn trust and guaranteed long-term survival for the technology. The conclusion most educators reach is that volatility, while often misunderstood, is part of the crypto market's growing pains. Volatility is an indication of active feedback, experimenting and constant adjusting. By introducing such facts in learning settings, professionals make market volatility less mystifying. They affirm that learning and not speculation, is the path to survival in this age of digital frontier. Ultimately, the end of these presentations isn't to forecast market destinations but to provide understanding. With technology and money more and more connected, it's this type of education that frees up human imagination to look beyond the headlines and get its hands on the models that are defining the future of global value exchange. Bank of England proposes ownership limits in new stablecoin rules
Source: Yahoo Finance UK    Published: 2025-11-10 12:18:25

Oops, something went wrong The Bank of England has partly softened proposals for ownership restrictions on UK stablecoins as it pushes forwards with new rules for the cryptocurrency. On Monday, the central bank said it is planning to temporarily impose caps on holdings of stablecoins, which are cryptocurrencies pegged directly to traditional assets such as real currency. The plans indicate that individuals will be limited to owning up to £20,000 in UK stablecoins that are considered systemically important. It said most businesses would have a limit of up to £10 million. The Bank of England has been assessing the potential opportunities and risks linked to digital currencies over the past year. Last month, Governor Andrew Bailey said the UK should “reap the benefits” of stablecoins as part of the country's financial system and said it would be “wrong” to be against them as a matter of principle. In a new consultation document, the Bank said it is “preparing for a future where new forms of digital money may be widely used for payments alongside existing ones, offering valuable choice for the public”. It said its proposed limits would include allowing stablecoin issuers to have as much as 60% of the backing assets in short-term government debt. The Bank said it is also considering central bank liquidity arrangements to “support systemic stablecoin issuers in times of stress”. Sarah Breeden, deputy governor for Financial Stability at the Bank, said: “Our objective remains to support innovation and build trust in this emerging form of money. “We've listened carefully to feedback and amended our proposals for achieving this, including on how stablecoin issuers interact with the Bank of England. “These proposals are fit for a future where stablecoins play a meaningful role in payments, giving the industry the clarity it needs to plan with confidence.” Error in retrieving data Sign in to access your portfolio Error in retrieving data Error in retrieving data Error in retrieving data Error in retrieving data

Can Bitcoin, Ethereum, XRP sustain recovery as US Senate advances bill
Source: FXStreet    Published: 2025-11-10 12:00:00

Rates & Charts News Analysis Economic Calendar Cryptos Video Education Brokers Trade Now ad Bitcoin (BTC) is trading above $106,000 at the time of writing on Monday as the cryptocurrency market broadly recovers following the United States (US) Senate vote to advance a bill likely to end the record-breaking government shutdown. Altcoins, including Ethereum (ETH) and Ripple (XRP), are following in Bitcoin's footsteps, creating new opportunities for investors. The US Senate has voted to advance a bill that would reopen the government and keep it afloat at least until the end of January amid a record-breaking government shutdown. Seven Senate Democrats and one independent joined Republicans to advance the bill through a 60-40 procedural vote on Sunday. This is expected to pave the way for full-year funding for an essential food aid program that currently serves over 42 million Americans, as well as for rehiring federal workers laid off during the government shutdown, according to the media platform Baker City Herald. Riskier assets, including crypto, are showing signs of recovery following Sunday's vote, pointing to improving sentiment. Macroeconomic uncertainty amid the government shutdown has kept Bitcoin significantly suppressed since the October 10 crash. Reopening the US government could further boost risk-on sentiment and bolster recovery in the cryptocurrency market before the end of the year. Bitcoin is trading marginally above $106,000 at the time of writing on Monday, supported by improving sentiment in the larger crypto market. The Relative Strength Index (RSI), at 45 and uptrending on the daily chart, indicates that bullish momentum is increasing. A sustained uptrend above the $106,000 short-term support may encourage investors to increase their risk exposure, possibly triggering a buy signal from the Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicator on the same daily chart. A break above the 200-day Exponential Moving Average (EMA) at $108,028 would affirm the bullish grip, increasing the odds of a Bitcoin price rally above the $110,000 round number resistance. Ethereum is holding above $3,600 and the 200-day EMA at $3,596 at the time of writing on Monday. The RSI is at 44 after a bullish crossover on the daily chart, which indicates that bullish momentum is rising. Investors will likely increase their risk exposure if the MACD indicator confirms a buy signal on the same daily chart. Other key levels of interest for traders are the 100-day EMA at 3,886 and the psychological resistance at $4,000. Meanwhile, retail demand for Ethereum has stabilized, with futures Open Interest (OI) rising to $41 billion on Monday, up from $39 billion the previous day. Such stability is required to improve investor confidence, following a prolonged risk-off sentiment since the October 10 deleveraging event. Furthermore, a steady increase in the OI would indicate that investors are ready to return and increase their risk exposure. As for XRP, bulls are tightening their grip, paving the way for a steady recovery above $2.50. The daily chart showcases a bullish picture, supported by a buy signal from the MACD indicator. Risk-on sentiment is expected to increase with the blue line lifting above the red signal line. The RSI on the same daily chart remains at 53 and rising, suggesting that bulls have the upper hand. A break above the 50-day EMA at $2.56 and the 100-day EMA at $2.65 would go a long way toward affirming the bullish outlook. Token launches influence demand and adoption among market participants. Listings on crypto exchanges deepen the liquidity for an asset and add new participants to an asset's network. This is typically bullish for a digital asset. A hack is an event in which an attacker captures a large volume of the asset from a DeFi bridge or hot wallet of an exchange or any other crypto platform via exploits, bugs or other methods. The exploiter then transfers these tokens out of the exchange platforms to ultimately sell or swap the assets for other cryptocurrencies or stablecoins. Such events often involve an en masse panic triggering a sell-off in the affected assets. Macroeconomic events like the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates influence crypto assets mainly through the direct impact they have on the US Dollar. An increase in interest rate typically negatively influences Bitcoin and altcoin prices, and vice versa. If the US Dollar index declines, risk assets and associated leverage for trading gets cheaper, in turn driving crypto prices higher. Halvings are typically considered bullish events as they slash the block reward in half for miners, constricting the supply of the asset. At consistent demand if the supply reduces, the asset's price climbs. Crypto Markets Today: Altcoins Lead Gains as Trump's Dividend Plan Sparks Retail Rally
Source: CoinDesk    Published: 2025-11-10 11:31:59

The crypto market enjoyed a period of upside over the weekend following two consecutive losing weeks. Bitcoin BTC$106,433.16 rose 4% in the past 24 hours and having risen as high as $106,500 is now trading around $106,000 as it attempts to steer itself away from the psychological level of support at $100,000. Ether ETH$3,614.58 added 6.5%. The altcoin market outperformed bitcoin, with bitcoin dominance falling to 59.1% from the Nov. 5 high of 60.1%. This is a signal that the touted $2,000 tariff dividend payment in the U.S. will serve as a boost to altcoins, as it did during the Covid-era. Decentralized finance (DeFi) protocols also saw a boost, with total value locked (TVL) rising to $142.8 billion, according to DeFiLlama data. Starknet Bridge TVL rose 20% to $913 million and Suilend also increased 20%. The rise in TVL might be attributed to asset appreciation, but since the SUI token is up only 7%, it's more indicative of investors depositing to generate a yield, reflecting confidence in the market. Attention Bitcoin (BTC) Bulls, Trump's Tariff Dividend Might Skip Direct Stimulus Checks
Source: CoinDesk    Published: 2025-11-10 09:19:32

The cryptocurrency market lit up on Sunday, with social media erupting in cheers as users hoped for new bull runs in bitcoin BTC$105,760.87 and tokens like XRP and DOGE fueled by stimulus checks, following President Donald Trump's announcement of a tariff dividend for low-income Americans on Truth Social. But the reality, as Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent later clarified, is more complicated. Bessent explained that the President's tariff dividend might be delivered through the tax cuts from his major economic policy bill earlier this year. "The $2,000 dividend could come in lots of forms, in lots of ways. It could be just the tax decreases that we are seeing on the president's agenda — no tax on tips, no tax on overtime, no tax on Social Security – deductibility on auto loans," Bessent told ABC's This Week when asked by Trump's social media post. These indirect measures, as mentioned by Bessent, may not trigger the same immediate surge in bitcoin, altcoins, or consumer spending as direct stimulus checks typically do. That's because checks provide quick, tangible cash inflows that can rapidly boost demand, while tax cuts tend to distribute benefits more gradually. It's the case of a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush — the certainty of direct cash inflow generally carries more immediate market impact than the uncertain promise of indirect measures. Bessent's clarification followed euphoric assumption that the announced dividend would come in the form of stimulus checks, drawing parallels to the COVID-era payments that were closely linked to unprecedented rallies in cryptocurrencies – particularly altcoins. The narrative lifted market valuations. Bitcoin BTC$105,760.87 rallied from roughly $103,000 to $105,000 on Sunday, extending gains to over $106,500 at one point during Monday's Asian hours. The leading cryptocurrency has gained 4% in the past 24 hours, with altcoins such as XRP, WLFI, PUMP, UNI, and ZEC rising 8% to 25%, respectively. The CoinDesk 20 Index has gained over 5% to 3,469 points. The rally, however, stalled at around 8:00AM UTC. It's also worth noting that drawing parallels with 2021 doesn't quite hold up. Back then, inflation was well below the Federal Reserve's 2% target, and interest rates were pinned near zero, both factors encouraging increased risk-taking and market exuberance. Today, rates stand around 4% following recent cuts, and inflation remains at least a full percentage point above the Fed's target. This raises a crucial question: whether recipients of the tariff dividend—whether through direct payments or indirect measures like tax cuts—will channel those funds into crypto trading or opt to save them instead. More For You Inside Zcash: Encrypted Money at Planetary Scale A deep dive into Zcash's zero-knowledge architecture, shielded transaction growth, and its path to becoming encrypted Bitcoin at scale. Crypto Market Today: Bitcoin and Ethereum Lead Rebound as Altcoins Show Mixed Moves
Source: TradingView    Published: 2025-11-10 06:33:00

The global crypto market today kicked off the week on a cautiously optimistic note after a subdued weekend of consolidation. Bitcoin BTCUSDT price reclaimed key resistance near $106,000 while Ethereum ETHUSDT price surged past $3,600, fueling renewed interest in the broader crypto market. Trading volumes are picking up across major exchanges as investors position for the week ahead, supported by positive ETF flow data and stable macro sentiment. However, altcoin performance remains uneven, with selective gains in Solana SOLUSDT and Avalanche AVAXUSDT while several mid-caps continue to lag. Bitcoin and Ethereum Extend Gains Bitcoin climbed 4.1% in the last 24 hours to hover near $106,034, signaling a steady rebound following last week's range-bound trade. The trading volume increased by over 35%, while the ETF inflows remain passive. Ethereum rose over 7% to around $3,643, outperforming BTC as on-chain activity picked up, and staking inflows continued to trend higher. The ETH/BTC ratio rose slightly, hinting at possible rotation into smart-contract-based assets. Altcoins Trade Mixed as SOL, DOGE Rise Moderately While XRP Thrives The altcoin market displayed mixed sentiment, with the Solana SOLUSDT price advancing 6.6% to around $167, supported by rising DeFi volumes and active wallet growth. Avalanche AVAXUSDT and Toncoin TONUSDT also posted modest gains, while Cardano ADAUSDT and Polygon (MATIC) stayed largely flat. XRP and Hyperliquid surged over 7%, while the BNB price just reclaimed levels above $1000. Despite strong showings from select tokens, market breadth remains limited—a sign that capital rotation is still concentrated in the large-cap space. Top Gainers, Losers, and Volume Leaders Market Sentiment and Overall Health Market sentiment indicators remain under fear, while the crypto market cap rises above $3.5 trillion with a decent rise in volume. Bitcoin's dominance sits near 59%, underscoring the concentration of capital in major assets, and the altcoin season index has risen slightly above the Bitcoin-dominant zone to reach 33. However, the future open interest continues to decline, indicating a drop in the momentum as traders are now closing their positions instead of opening new ones. While broader crypto market health shows tentative improvement, traders are watching whether rising volumes translate into a sustained rally. For now, the tone remains cautiously bullish—driven by BTC stability and selective altcoin strength rather than a full-scale breakout. Outlook If Bitcoin maintains support above $105,000 and Ethereum sustains momentum above $3,600, a short-term push toward higher resistance levels appears likely. Analysts expect volatility to remain contained ahead of midweek macro data and potential ETF inflow updates. Broader participation from mid-caps could signal a stronger recovery trend heading into the second half of November. FAQs Bitcoin and Ethereum recovered key levels, trading volumes increased, and sentiment improved as investors positioned for the week ahead. Higher trading volumes, stable macro conditions, and steady ETF flows are supporting Bitcoin's rebound from last week's consolidation. Ethereum is seeing stronger on-chain activity, higher staking inflows, and mild rotation from BTC into smart-contract assets. If BTC holds above $105,000 and ETH stays over $3,600, short-term upside is likely, though volatility may stay contained until midweek data arrives. Select market data provided by ICE Data Services. Select reference data provided by FactSet. Copyright © 2025 FactSet Research Systems Inc.Copyright © 2025, American Bankers Association. CUSIP Database provided by FactSet Research Systems Inc. All rights reserved. SEC fillings and other documents provided by Quartr.© 2025 TradingView, Inc.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Crypto Market Today: Bitcoin and Ethereum Lead Rebound as Altcoins Show Mixed Moves
Source: TradingView    Published: 2025-11-10 06:33:00

The global crypto market today kicked off the week on a cautiously optimistic note after a subdued weekend of consolidation. Bitcoin BTCUSDT price reclaimed key resistance near $106,000 while Ethereum ETHUSDT price surged past $3,600, fueling renewed interest in the broader crypto market. Trading volumes are picking up across major exchanges as investors position for the week ahead, supported by positive ETF flow data and stable macro sentiment. However, altcoin performance remains uneven, with selective gains in Solana SOLUSDT and Avalanche AVAXUSDT while several mid-caps continue to lag. Bitcoin and Ethereum Extend Gains Bitcoin climbed 4.1% in the last 24 hours to hover near $106,034, signaling a steady rebound following last week's range-bound trade. The trading volume increased by over 35%, while the ETF inflows remain passive. Ethereum rose over 7% to around $3,643, outperforming BTC as on-chain activity picked up, and staking inflows continued to trend higher. The ETH/BTC ratio rose slightly, hinting at possible rotation into smart-contract-based assets. Altcoins Trade Mixed as SOL, DOGE Rise Moderately While XRP Thrives The altcoin market displayed mixed sentiment, with the Solana SOLUSDT price advancing 6.6% to around $167, supported by rising DeFi volumes and active wallet growth. Avalanche AVAXUSDT and Toncoin TONUSDT also posted modest gains, while Cardano ADAUSDT and Polygon (MATIC) stayed largely flat. XRP and Hyperliquid surged over 7%, while the BNB price just reclaimed levels above $1000. Despite strong showings from select tokens, market breadth remains limited—a sign that capital rotation is still concentrated in the large-cap space. Top Gainers, Losers, and Volume Leaders Market Sentiment and Overall Health Market sentiment indicators remain under fear, while the crypto market cap rises above $3.5 trillion with a decent rise in volume. Bitcoin's dominance sits near 59%, underscoring the concentration of capital in major assets, and the altcoin season index has risen slightly above the Bitcoin-dominant zone to reach 33. However, the future open interest continues to decline, indicating a drop in the momentum as traders are now closing their positions instead of opening new ones. While broader crypto market health shows tentative improvement, traders are watching whether rising volumes translate into a sustained rally. For now, the tone remains cautiously bullish—driven by BTC stability and selective altcoin strength rather than a full-scale breakout. Outlook If Bitcoin maintains support above $105,000 and Ethereum sustains momentum above $3,600, a short-term push toward higher resistance levels appears likely. Analysts expect volatility to remain contained ahead of midweek macro data and potential ETF inflow updates. Broader participation from mid-caps could signal a stronger recovery trend heading into the second half of November. FAQs Bitcoin and Ethereum recovered key levels, trading volumes increased, and sentiment improved as investors positioned for the week ahead. Higher trading volumes, stable macro conditions, and steady ETF flows are supporting Bitcoin's rebound from last week's consolidation. Ethereum is seeing stronger on-chain activity, higher staking inflows, and mild rotation from BTC into smart-contract assets. If BTC holds above $105,000 and ETH stays over $3,600, short-term upside is likely, though volatility may stay contained until midweek data arrives. Select market data provided by ICE Data Services. All rights reserved. SEC fillings and other documents provided by Quartr.© 2025 TradingView, Inc.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


SCIENCE

Multilingualism protects against accelerated aging in cross-sectional and longitudinal analyses of 27 European countries
Source: Nature    Published: 2025-11-10 16:04:35

Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript. Advertisement Nature Aging (2025)Cite this article Aging trajectories are influenced by modifiable risk factors, and prior evidence has hinted that multilingualism may have protective potential. However, reliance on suboptimal health markers, small samples, inadequate confounder control and a focus on clinical cohorts led to mixed findings and limited applicability to healthy populations. Here, we developed biobehavioral age gaps, quantifying delayed or accelerated aging in 86,149 participants across 27 European countries. National surveys provided individual-level positive (functional ability, education, cognition) and adverse (cardiometabolic conditions, female sex, sensory impairments) factors, while country-level multilingualism served as an aggregate exposure. Biobehavioral factors predicted age (R2 = 0.24, r = 0.49, root mean squared error = 8.61), with positive factors linked to delayed aging and adverse factors to accelerated aging. Multilingualism emerged as a protective factor in cross-sectional (odds ratio = 0.46) and longitudinal (relative risk = 0.70) analyses, whereas monolingualism increased risk of accelerated aging (odds ratio = 2.11; relative risk = 1.43). Effects persisted after adjusting for linguistic, physical, social and sociopolitical exposomes. These results underscore the protective role of multilingualism and its broad applicability for global health initiatives. This is a preview of subscription content, access via your institution Access Nature and 54 other Nature Portfolio journals Get Nature+, our best-value online-access subscription $32.99 / 30 days cancel any time Subscribe to this journal Receive 12 digital issues and online access to articles $119.00 per year only $9.92 per issue Buy this article Prices may be subject to local taxes which are calculated during checkout All databases used in this study are publicly accessible. Indicators of GDP, air quality, socioeconomic inequality (Gini index) and migration were obtained from the World Bank's platform (https://databank.worldbank.org/). Country-level gender inequality indexes (GII) are available on the WHO's website (https://www.who.int/data/nutrition/nlis/info/gender-inequality-index-(gii)/. Sociopolitical exposome indicators are available through the Global State of Democracy Indices (https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/dataset-resources/). Country-level percentages of foreign-speaking languages are sourced from the Eurostat database covering 2007, 2011, 2016 and 2022 waves (https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php?/title=Foreign_language_skills_statistics/). Linguistic exposome indicators for the number of stable and institutional languages per European country are available from Ethnologue (https://www.ethnologue.com/). The two most spoken languages per country are sourced from the ‘Europeans and their languages' Eurobarometer survey by the European Commission (https://languageknowledge.eu/countries-list/). The typological distance between languages was estimated using the Perplexity metric available at https://github.com/gamallo/Perplexity/. Analysis code (https://github.com/euroladbrainlat/Biobehavioral-age-gaps-Multilingualism/tree/main/scripts/) and preprocessed data containing individual BAG estimates (https://github.com/euroladbrainlat/Biobehavioral-age-gaps-Multilingualism/tree/main/scripts/main/data/) are freely available on GitHub. Associations between number of spoken languages and BAGs across age cohorts (n = 86,149 participants). A) Odds ratio (OR) estimates from the cross-sectional analysis and B) relative risk (RR) estimates from the longitudinal analysis, both stratified by age. Across designs, results show that risk of accelerated aging increases with age among monolinguals. For individuals speaking one additional language, the protective effect weakens with age. In contrast, speaking two or more additional languages is linked to progressively stronger protection with advancing age. A Revolutionary New Cancer Therapy Only Needs Light to Kill Bad Cells
Source: Popular Mechanics    Published: 2025-11-10 14:30:00

Known as near-infrared photothermal therapy, this light-based treatment promises to cause less damage to healthy cells than chemotherapy. Gear-obsessed editors choose every product we review. We may earn commission if you buy from a link. Why Trust Us? Here's what you'll learn when you read this story: Chemotherapy is our most effective tool at fighting many forms of cancer, but due to its mostly indiscriminate nature, healthy tissues are often caught in the crossfire between these radiative drugs and cancer cells. Scientists have made remarkable progress trying to limit the debilitating side effects of chemotherapy—even looking to the biology of extremophiles like tardigrades for inspiration—while others have investigated ways to fight cancer through different means entirely. It's this second strategy that's become the sole focus of one team of researchers at the University of Texas at Austin (UT Austin) and the University of Porto in Portugal. In a new paper published in the journal ACS Nano, the team provides details of a cancer-fighting treatment known as near-infrared photothermal therapy, which relies on light and nanomaterials—specifically, tin-based two-dimensional nanoflakes, or SnOx (Sn is tin on the periodic table)—to essentially serve a fatal dose of heat via lasers to cancer cells while leaving healthy cells untouched. “Our goal was to create a treatment that is not only effective but also safe and accessible,” Jean Anne Incorvia, a co-author of the study from UT Austin, said in a press statement. “With the combination of LED light and SnOx nanoflakes, we've developed a method to precisely target cancer cells while leaving healthy cells untouched.” According to Wired, the system relies on near-infrared LEDs (NIR-LEDs) that emit light at 810 nanometers, which is the same wavelength that scientists use for photobiomodulation, used to stimulate cellular and healing processes. Once a sample is irradiated, the tiny nanoflakes get to work infiltrating cancerous cells, absorbing light, and transferring that light into heat to eventually destroy the cell. Preliminary results when tested with human cells show that the treatment killed up to 92 percent of skin cancer cells and 50 percent of colorectal cancer cells—all while protecting healthy cells in the process. The entire system only costs $530 and can irradiate 24 samples at a time, meaning that near-infrared photothermal therapy could also be an affordable therapeutic option. “Our ultimate goal is to make this technology available to patients everywhere, especially places where access to specialized equipment is limited, with fewer side effects and lower cost,” Artur Pinto, a co-author of the study from the University of Porto, said in a press statement. “For skin cancers in particular, we envision that one day, treatment could move from the hospital to the patient's home. A portable device could be placed on the skin after surgery to irradiate and destroy any remaining cancer cells, reducing the risk of recurrence.” The authors admit that there's more work to do. For one, they hope to explore more catalyst materials and improve efficiency while moving this treatment through more clinical trials. Today, cancer remains the second-leading cause of death worldwide, but it looks like a new light-based ally is ready to enter the fight. You can find his previous stuff at Gizmodo and Paste if you look hard enough. Lost Revolutionary War Barracks Found in Virginia Are There More Humans on Earth Than We Thought? Ancient Humans Survived a Massive Climate Crisis. Archaeologists Just Discovered How.
Source: Popular Mechanics    Published: 2025-11-10 14:00:00

Paleolithic tools found at the Namorotukunan site in Kenya suggest that early Homo species kept their technology going even through natural disasters. Gear-obsessed editors choose every product we review. We may earn commission if you buy from a link. Why Trust Us? Here's what you'll learn when you read this story: The remote Namorotukunan archaeological site in Kenya's Turkana Basin can be punishingly hot and arid, with Lake Turkana offering the only relief for a passing zebra or gazelle. It was not, however, always this parched. Around 2.75 million years ago, the region was once covered by wetlands, which dried up into seemingly endless miles of grassland and desert. And somehow, despite the dramatic changes in climate, human ancestors managed to survive there for hundreds of thousands of years. Namorotukunan has revealed more about how our hominin predecessors adapted to sometimes drastic climate shifts in climate. Stone tools found at the site, once inhabited by the Oldowan civilization of Lower Paleolithic Africa, show a period of technological evolution spanning some 300,000 years from 2.75 to 2.4 million years ago (this is one of the rare Oldowan sites over 2.6 million years old). Susana Carvalho—a researcher from the Department of Science at Gorongosa National Park in Sofala, Mozambique—wanted to see how ancient toolmakers weathered the paleoenvironment. “Detailed knowledge of environmental patterns within this region allows us to explore the interplay between periods of environmental change and the presence of an early Oldowan techno-complex that first evolved in the late Pliocene, and emphasizes temporal continuity throughout the Early Pleistocene, in eastern Africa,” she said in a study recently published in the journal Nature Communications. Hominins are thought to have begun making tools over 3 million years ago, and other East African sites have turned up Oldowan artifacts that represent the most ancient systematic tool production system. The oldest evidence of toolmaking shows that percussive technology, meaning the pounding, grinding, or flaking of stone into objects such as spear points and blades. Many of the tools found at Namorotukunan had been flaked to create sharp edges. In the Koobi Fora formation of sedimentary rock, where the Turkana Basin lies, artifacts have been discovered in what were once the beds of paleorivers that intertwined with each other. Sometime between 3.6 and 3.4 million years ago, a volcanic eruption reshaped the landscape around Namorotukunan, and a humid floodplain formed in its aftermath. Fossils of palms and sedges from before 2.8 million years ago suggest a high water level in the region. From 2.8 to 2.7 million years ago, paleorivers transformed the landscape as the climate became drier. Wildfires swept across Turkana Basin, leaving behind microcharcoals from the vegetation they burned, while shrubs and grasses replaced plants that needed more water to thrive. 2.2 million years ago, the paleolake that was a precursor to Lake Turkana flooded, receded, and flooded again. Then, the entire expanse gradually went from submerged to nearly desiccated. Hominins who lived at Namorotukunan persevered in making these tools through all sorts of weather changes and natural disasters. They apparently preferred certain types of rock, such as basalt, and later chalcedony and jasper. These stones fracture consistently, making them easier to work with and showing that these ancient people understood the mechanical properties of rocks to some extent. Morphological features of the tools they manufactured indicate that they had a grasp on some aspects of stone knapping—the craft of striking stones to shape them—which echoes the level of technological advancement at other early Oldowan sites. The levels of rock in which artifacts were found helped give Carvalho and her team an idea as to which time period they were from. Most were found in rock strata made of sands and gravels which have long since fossilized, and while there has been some damage to these tools over the eons, their razor-thin edges were preserved. Also unearthed at the site were animal bones that show butchery marks most likely made by these same tools. “As these shifts impacted different parts of Africa separately, it is likely that such selective pressures on tool use impacted different populations at different times,” said Carvalho. “This period of aridification played a role in shaping the ecological context in which the behaviors of our human ancestors evolved.” Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Elizabeth Rayne is a creature who writes. Her work has appeared in Popular Mechanics, Ars Technica, SYFY WIRE, Space.com, Live Science, Den of Geek, Forbidden Futures and Collective Tales. She lurks right outside New York City with her parrot, Lestat. When not writing, she can be found drawing, playing the piano or shapeshifting. Fingerprints Vanish from Fired Bullets. Scientists Can Now Identify Them Anyway.
Source: Popular Mechanics    Published: 2025-11-10 13:30:00

Long thought to be impossible, fingerprinting bullets is now possible thanks to a new electrochemical process that makes hidden ridges visible in seconds. Here's what you'll learn when you read this story: In October of 1904, the St. Louis Metropolitan Police Department became the first in the nation to create a fingerprint bureau (inspired in part by the policing challenges of the 1904 World's Fair). And in the ensuing 120 years, not only has the crime-fighting technique spread far and wide, but it has improved in both reliability and accuracy, and is now even incorporating artificial intelligence in an attempt to learn more about human fingerprints themselves. However, all of that time, scientists haven't cracked arguably the most important problem facing fingerprinting: You can't pull prints off of bullet casings. Because of the intense temperatures, gas, and friction applied to a bullet when fired, biological residue (read: fingerprints) typically doesn't survive the process. If crime scene investigators could somehow lift prints off these littered casings... well, that'd be quite the smoking gun. A new study led by scientists at Maynooth University in Ireland might be making impressive headway on that very idea. As reported in the journal Forensic Chemistry, authors Colm McKeever and Eithne Dempsey wrote that a new electrochemical technique can draw chemicals to the surface of the casing when a low voltage is applied, filling tiny gaps between fingerprint ridges almost instantly. “Using the burnt material that remains on the surface of the casing as a stencil, we can deposit specific materials in between the gaps, allowing for the visualization,” McKeever said in a press statement. “Currently, the best case of forensic analysis of ammunition casings is to match it to the gun that fired it. But we hope a method like this could match it back to the actual person who loaded the gun.” The team tested this next-gen fingerprinting technique on brass, as it's the most widely used material for bullet casings (certain aluminum alloys and even steel are used in some cases), and found that this electrochemical process even worked on samples as old as 16 months. But the best part may be that at the heart of this technology is a device known as a potentiostat (which is what controls the voltage), and it can be as small as a mobile phone, meaning that future kits could be compact enough to carry into the field. “With this method, we have turned the ammunition casing into an electrode, allowing us to drive chemical reactions at the surface of the casing,” McKeever said in a press statement. The authors note that this study is only a proof-of-principle first phase in visualizing fingerprints on challenging surfaces. Further work will need to be done to shore up the technique's accuracy before it's exported around the world as a crime-fighting tool (time well spent, considering conventional fingerprinting doesn't exactly have a sterling success record). The team hopes that this process could also be applied to other metallic surfaces, including knives, coins, and other types of firearms. For more than a century, bullet casings have only informed law enforcement about the gun used in a crime. But this new research presents a major possibility that, someday soon, they could provide much more than that. Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Darren lives in Portland, has a cat, and writes/edits about sci-fi and how our world works. You can find his previous stuff at Gizmodo and Paste if you look hard enough. Lost Revolutionary War Barracks Found in Virginia Are There More Humans on Earth Than We Thought? Hamilton Smith obituary: molecular biologist who co-discovered precise molecular scissors for cutting DNA
Source: Nature    Published: 2025-11-10 12:33:45

Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript. Advertisement J. Craig Venter is founder and chief executive of the J. Craig Venter Institute in La Jolla, California and in Rockville, Maryland. Search author on: PubMed Google Scholar Credit: Keystone Press/Alamy Hamilton (Ham) Smith co-discovered type II restriction enzymes, molecular scissors that cut DNA at precise sequence sites, which proved to be an essential tool for the emerging field of molecular biology. For this work he shared the 1978 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with Werner Arber and Daniel Nathans. Smith began a second career in 1993, when he agreed to collaborate with me on sequencing the genome of the bacterium Haemophilus influenzae. On its publication in 1995, it was the first complete genome of any organism. That fortunate collaboration led to the first draft human genome sequence in 2001, and then to the first cell made from a synthetic genome in 2010. Smith was a scientist's scientist, working in the laboratory almost every day and quietly being an inspiration, friend and a collaborator to all his colleagues. A wealth of discovery built on the Human Genome Project — by the numbers A wealth of discovery built on the Human Genome Project — by the numbers Born in New York City, Smith grew up in Champaign-Urbana, Illinois, where his father was a college professor. Smith discovered biology while studying mathematics at the University of California, Berkeley, and went on to receive his medical degree from Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore, Maryland, in 1956. Following his military service in the US Navy, and a medical residency at Henry Ford hospital in Detroit, Michigan, in 1962, Smith received a fellowship from the US National Institutes of Health to work with Myron Levine — a pioneer in infectious-disease research — at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. Studying the bacteriophage P22, a virus that infects the bacterium Salmonella Typhimurium, he mastered DNA isolation techniques that became an essential component of all his main contributions to science. In 1967, Smith joined the microbiology department at Johns Hopkins. Beginning work on H. influenzae, he discovered a restriction enzyme by studying changes in DNA viscosity. He used several clever techniques to prove that the enzyme recognized a unique DNA sequence, long before the advent of DNA sequencing, and published two key papers in the Journal of Molecular Biology in 1970 (H. O. Smith and K. W. Wilcox J. Mol. Biol. 51, 379–391 (1970); T. J. Kelly Jr and H. O. Smith J. Mol. Biol. 51, 393–409; 1970). His parents were driving to the grocery shop on 12 October 1978 when the news came over their car radio that Hamilton Smith at Johns Hopkins had won the Nobel prize. His mother told him that she looked at his father and said, “Do you suppose there is another Hamilton Smith at Hopkins?” In 1993, Smith and I met at a conference in Bilbao, Spain. I had founded the Institute for Genomic Research (TIGR) in Rockville, Maryland, the year before and Smith agreed to join the science advisory board. At his suggestion, we decided to collaborate on sequencing the genome of H. influenzae using my idea of whole-genome shotgun sequencing. The method is dependent on achieving a perfect statistical Poisson distribution of the DNA fragments that cover the genome in a genomic sequencing library, and Smith developed techniques to achieve this. We sequenced 25,000 fragments and mathematically assembled them into the complete circular genome. After this, Smith joined TIGR and its successor firm, the J. Craig Venter Institute, where he stayed for the remaining 25 years of his career. We went on to collaborate on dozens of other genomes, including the Neisseria meningitidis genome that led to the development of the first meningococcal B vaccine that has saved thousands of lives. or Nature 647, 311 (2025) doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-025-03635-y The author declares no competing interests. How should ‘mirror life' research be restricted? Debate heats up Geneticist J. Competitive packages, strong research support, housing, visa/family aid.
