Unsolved Mystery: Missing camper from Trinity County vanished amid wildfires
Source: Action News Now    Published: 2025-11-10 13:12:00

Kelli Saam is an anchor for Action News Now and rejoined the team in 2021. Kelli Saam is an anchor for Action News Now and rejoined the team in 2021. Dustin Martin of Trinity County was last seen in 2015. HAYFORK, Calif. - A decade-long mystery surrounds the disappearance of Dustin Martin, last seen camping in the Post Mountain area of Trinity County near Hayfork. Martin, who was 44 years old at the time, vanished on July 20, 2015, just before a lightning storm hit the area. The resulting fires, road closures, and evacuations hindered law enforcement's ability to conduct an immediate search. A friend found Martin's campsite with his dog left unattended, along with his wallet and cellphone in his tent. Martin is described as standing 5 feet 11 inches tall and weighing 165 pounds. He has black or grey hair, brown eyes, and a tattoo of a coyote on his right arm. Today, Martin would be 54 years old. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact the Trinity County Sheriff's Office at (530) 623-2611. Kelli Saam is an anchor for Action News Now and rejoined the team in 2021. Kelli Saam is an anchor for Action News Now and rejoined the team in 2021. What Do You Believe About Extraterrestrial Intelligent Life Beyond Earth?
Source: Avi Loeb – Medium    Published: 2025-11-10 11:14:07

Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in -- Listen Share I'm grateful that my posts have reached 100,000 followers on Medium. This milestone tells me something important: curiosity about science lives in all of us, regardless of our backgrounds. Today, I'm inviting you, my science-oriented readership, to participate in a real academic research. I am collaborating with Prof. Gershon Tenenbaum and Dr. Omer Eldadi on a study examining how scientifically engaged individuals perceive the question of extraterrestrial intelligence beyond Earth. The research is straightforward: What do you believe about the existence of intelligent life beyond Earth? How do your beliefs compare to what you think others believe — both in your social circle and among scientific experts? Your participation takes just 5 minutes and contributes to academic research that will be published in a peer reviewed journal and shared here on Medium with all of you. The survey is completely anonymous. Take the survey (here) https://idc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_elf3G9qfDpfG3bw This study targets readers like you, people who actively engage with scientific ideas, because understanding how the scientifically literate public thinks about extraterrestrial intelligence is crucial for improving science communication in this field. Science advances through curiosity and evidence, not assumptions. By participating, you're expanding our understanding of how beliefs about one of humanity's most fundamental questions are formed and shared within science-oriented communities. We should maintain the humility to learn rather than presume we know the answers in advance. Your contribution to this research embodies that scientific spirit. Here's hoping your participation will illuminate what we think about our place in our cosmic neighborhood. With gratitude, Avi Loeb ABOUT THE AUTHOR Avi Loeb is the head of the Galileo Project, founding director of Harvard University's — Black Hole Initiative, director of the Institute for Theory and Computation at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, and the former chair of the astronomy department at Harvard University (2011–2020). He is a former member of the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology and a former chair of the Board on Physics and Astronomy of the National Academies. He is the bestselling author of “Extraterrestrial: The First Sign of Intelligent Life Beyond Earth” and a co-author of the textbook “Life in the Cosmos”, both published in 2021. The paperback edition of his new book, titled “Interstellar”, was published in August 2024. -- -- Avi Loeb is the Baird Professor of Science and Institute director at Harvard University and the bestselling author of “Extraterrestrial” and "Interstellar". Blockbuster Horror Goes Live: Illusion-infused ‘Paranormal Activity' play arrives at the Ahmanson Theatre
Source: Los Angeles Downtown News    Published: 2025-11-10 08:00:00

Sunshine and a few afternoon clouds. High near 90F. Winds light and variable.. Considerable clouds this evening. Some decrease in clouds late. Low near 60F. Winds light and variable. Updated: November 10, 2025 @ 9:57 am “Paranormal Activity” tells the story of a couple that recently moved hoping to escape the past — only to discover their troubles have followed them. Patrick Heusinger is one of the stars. The screams of fright recently heard in London and Chicago — as well as those expected to flow through Downtown's Ahmanson Theatre this month — might never have happened if not for an accident decades ago. That's when then three-year-old Chris Fisher fell off a stool, broke his leg and ended up hospitalized for six weeks. His parents bought him a magic set to pass the time. While magic remained part of his life, he began working behind the scenes in theater, unaware that eventually both worlds would merge. Now an acclaimed illusionist for plays, including Broadway's “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” and “Stranger Things: The First Shadow,” Fisher has created some of his most advanced and scary effects for “Paranormal Activity.” Inspired by the movie franchise, and starring Cher Álvarez and Patrick Heusinger, “Paranormal Activity” is running Nov. 13 through Dec. 7. Writer Levi Holloway and director Felix Barrett are both theatrical horror veterans. The story follows a couple who have recently moved, hoping to escape strange experiences of the past, only to find that their supernatural troubles appear to have followed them. After months of preparation to make each creepy and scary moment succeed for its world premiere in London, Fisher was optimistic but not sure it would all work until the first audience reacted. “You always hope that you're going to get those moments, and I think one of the illusions is probably the most satisfying illusion that I think I've ever designed, because the reactions it gets are crazy,” Fisher said. “I think what we've learned is illusion and horror and suspense is all about timing.” Fisher spent years as a theatrical stage and company manager, performing tricks for the company's amusement, until illusionist Jamie Harrison recruited him for a production of the musical “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.” They also joined forces on the “Harry Potter” and “Stranger Things” shows. For “Paranormal Activity,” Fisher, who is working without Harrison this time, has been part of the creation process since near the beginning. “That way we could get the illusions fully integrated into the show,” he said. “In fact, some of the set was designed because of what the illusion had to be. It also helped that I had worked in theater for a while, because I understand about sound and lighting. So, when I need an illusion to do a certain thing, I know what's needed for each department.” As he does with all writers and directors, Fisher told Holloway and Barrett not to focus on whether an effect could be done but rather focus on their vision — leaving it to him to make it a reality. One of the biggest challenges for each production is making sure the cast knows how to work with his illusions, beginning with explaining why they shouldn't reveal any secrets. “Sometimes when you find out how something's done, it can be quite disappointing,” he said. “So, I talk through that psychology of why we keep the secret. Then I talk to them about how we use misdirection, use sleight of hand. It's hard for actors because they're not magicians and sometimes I need to guide them to make what they're doing feel natural.” As the couple going through the haunting each performance, Álvarez and Heusinger said the effects, along with other technical aspects heighten the play in ways that still surprise them. “Chris is such a magnificent artist, and these illusions and effects are wonderful,” Heusinger said. “You feel in very safe hands. There's one moment where, with every audience, it feels as if they're going to give a standing ovation because they're so excited about it.” Still, not every effect always lands the same way each time, and the cast has to go with it. But the actors said that the strong script keeps everything working. “It's a testimony to the way Levi wrote this that so many people who have been watching say it feels like they're invading, like they shouldn't be there,” Álvarez said. “The language is so real.” “Paranormal Activity,” which co-stars Cher Álvarez, is inspired by the movie franchise. The intensity of both the story and relying on technical aspects means Álvarez and Heusinger rely heavily on mutual trust, knowing they will be there for each other regardless of what happens — including reactions from the crowds. “I can say that the audience screams, and I mean screams every night, multiple times, and it's not that we're not running out and going ‘Boo' from behind their backs. It is properly scary.” WHEN: Various times Nov. 13 to Dec. 7 WHERE: Ahmanson Theatre, 135 N. Grand Avenue, Los Angeles COST: Prices vary INFO: 213-628-2772, centertheatregroup.org Never miss an issue. Sign up for free today.
